title: Indexing and Searching (Inverted Files, Boolean, Pattern)

content.text: How do we search billions of pages in milliseconds? We move from sequential scanning to direct access via indexing.
content.hook: Searching without an index is like reading every book in the library to find one quote.

content.definition: The core data structure of all modern search engines. A mapping from words to the lists of documents they appear in.
content.text: Structure: 1. Vocabulary (The words), 2. Postings Lists (The IDs), 3. Payloads (Frequency/Position).

content.description: Logic of mapping terms to document identifiers.

content.text: Searching by combining terms with AND, OR, and NOT. These are solved by merging sorted postings lists.
Scanning the raw text file from start to finish (e.g. grep).
content.problem: Too slow for massive data, but necessary for complex pattern matching that isn't indexed.

slides.title: Pattern Matching & Structural Queries
items: Pattern Searching: Using Automata or Suffix Trees to find wildcards (*) in indexed text.
Structural Searching: Using the index to find keywords within specific document segments (like Title or Author).
Proximity Searching: Finding words within 'N' positions of each other.

content.text: Making the index fit in RAM. We compress the postings lists using Gap Encoding.
outcomes: Bit-level Compression: Variable Byte, Gamma/Delta codes.

formula.description: Delta Gaps (Gap Encoding) reduce the magnitude of numbers in a postings list by storing differences between consecutive document IDs rather than absolute values.
